pr_title: Redesign IIDM shunt compensator allowing non linear shunts + updated conversions + updated serialization

timeline.bodyText: This function will be shared by ShuntCompensatorLinearModel and ShuntCompensatorNonLinearModel, right ? Why cannot we have simply getbPerSection(int sectionIndex) ?
timeline.author: annetill
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,28 @@
+/**
+ * Copyright (c) 2020, RTE (http://www.rte-france.com)
+ * This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public
+ * License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this
+ * file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/.
+ */

+
+/**
+ * @author Miora Ralambotiana <miora.ralambotiana at rte-france.com>
+ */
+public interface ShuntCompensatorModel {
+
+    /**
+     * Get the section susceptance in S of the section with a given section number if it exists.
+     * Return 0 if sectionIndex is equal to 0 (disconnected state).
+     * Throw an exception if such a section does not exist.
+     */
+    double getBSection(int sectionIndex);

replies.bodyText: Do you have any other idea ?
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: Yes, I agree with your proposition. It will probably be clearer.
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: getbPerSection or getBPerSection ?
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: For consistence, we might as well rename as getBPerSection
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: Why do you need this function ?
timeline.author: annetill
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,54 @@ +/** + * Copyright (c) 2020, RTE (http://www.rte-france.com) + * This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public + * License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this + * file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. + */ +package com.powsybl.iidm.network; + +import java.util.List; +import java.util.Optional; + +/** + * @author Miora Ralambotiana + */ +public interface ShuntCompensatorNonLinearModel extends ShuntCompensatorModel { + + interface Section { + + /** + * Get the susceptance in S of the section. + */ + double getB(); + + /** + * Get the conductance in S of the section. + */ + double getG(); + } + + /** + * Get an optional of the section associated with a given section number if it exists. + * If such a section does not exist, return an empty optional. + * + */ + Optional
getSection(int sectionIndex); + + /** + * Get all the sections associated with their section number. + */ + List
getSections(); + + /** + * For a given section number, add a section with a given susceptance and conductance in S to the model. + * If a section already exists for this section number, respectively replace its susceptance and conductance with the given susceptance and conductance. + * Throw an exception if the section index equals to 0 (corresponds to disconnected state). + */ + ShuntCompensatorNonLinearModel addOrReplaceSection(int sectionIndex, double b, double g); + + /** + * Remove the section associated with a given section number if it exists and the current section count is different of the given section number. + * Else, throw an exception. + */ + ShuntCompensatorNonLinearModel removeLastSection();

replies.bodyText: Otherwise, it would be impossible to remove shunt section in non linear shunt (for development purposes for example)
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: I am not sure to get what you mean :-) The function is not to remove a given section, just the last one.
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText:
When you have a non linear shunt, what you can want to do is:

adding a new section
replacing the value of an existing section
removing an existing section

However, when you remove an existing section, it cannot be one in the middle (you cannot have a "hole" in your section list), so it is necessarily the last section. It occurs to me that a method can however be added to remove the last 2, 3, etc sections of a non linear shunt and not only the last one... (for now, to do that we have to call removeLastSection 2, 3, etc times)
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: Side note, it is the same for adding a new section, you cannot add a section with a index strictly superior to the last index + 1 to avoid "holes"
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: Thanks so Indeed this remove function is using by the function addOrReplace ? Why have you decided to put it in the interface and not just in the implementation?
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: No it is used when we really want to remove a section! addOrReplace can not remove a section, only replacing a value or adding a section.
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText:
I don't understand why is a problem to remove a section that is not the last.
In any case if you remove a section it doesn't make sense anymore to update back the original model so we can allow everything.
replies.author: geofjamg

replies.bodyText:
Okay, just a question: when a section is removed, should all the cumulated susceptances and admittances of following sections be calculated again or does it just mean it will not be possible anymore to activate a certain section count to access a given cumulated susceptance and admittance?
For example, if we have:
<shunt id="SHUNT">
  <shuntNonLinearModel>
    <section b="1.0" g="1.0"/>
    <section b="2.0" g="2.0"/>
    <section b="4.0" g="5.0"/>
  </shuntNonLinearModel>
</shunt>
If the section section is removed, should we have:
<shunt id="SHUNT">
  <shuntNonLinearModel>
    <section b="1.0" g="1.0"/>
    <section b="4.0" g="5.0"/>
  </shuntNonLinearModel>
</shunt>
or:
<shunt id="SHUNT">
  <shuntNonLinearModel>
    <section b="1.0" g="1.0"/>
    <section b="3.0" g="4.0"/>
  </shuntNonLinearModel>
</shunt>
?
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText:
I guess my question should be: do you know the use case where a section is "removed" (for maintenance, etc) and what is the behavior of the shunt in this case?
Edit: If there is no real use case, this method might not be useful
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: The name chosen is not so clear. See remark above.
timeline.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText: I fall in this exception on some TSOs, included for our French network !
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: Corrected in CGMES conversion
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: I fall in this exception with NGESO network.
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: I will check but I think I will add a fix on CGMES converter here.
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: Is it in the CGMES documentation that section 0 should have a b equal to zero ?
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText:
It doesn't but I don't know if it makes sense?
Actually I think it is linked to your other remark: to be "realistic", it doesn't really matter if b is 0 at section 0 as long as there is a section where b is 0 (a section where the shunt can be considered as disconnected). Maybe we should go in that sense? However in CGMES datasets, even in explicit section 0, the susceptance is always 0 from what I've seen.
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText:
From Implementation guide:
Use the cim:ShuntCompensator.sections to control the impedance where cim:ShuntCompensator.sections=0 means zero admittance. For linear shunt this means multiplying with the per section admittance results in zero impedance. For nonlinear shunts the cim:NonlinearShuntCompensatorPoint.sectionNumber=0 shall have the corresponding admittance values equal zero.
It means that we should leave it to zero in IIDM...
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: Okay, so we keep ignoring it then?
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText:
I don't understand the meaning of a zero admittance section. For me this should not be a requirement in IIDM but we need to accept it in order to keep the same number of section between CGMES and IIDM and then be able to update back the current section in case of regulation.
Why having a special meaning for section 0? section 0 is just the first one and could have an admittance. Also the shunt should accept 0 sections activated.
replies.author: geofjamg

replies.bodyText:
In what I implemented, section 0 is in fact the disconnected state (like linear shunts: when sectionIndex == 0 , b and g are also at 0 because they are proportional to sectionIndex ; this is also the convention adopted in CGMES). We can not do things like this but this would imply:

that a load-flow can disconnect the shunt's terminal or we create a parameter to indicate if the shunt is in disconnected state or not (and in which case, we do not consider its b and g)
having different definitions of what section 0 is for linear and non linear shunts (that might be leading to different behaviors after a load-flow)
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: It is wierd that CGMES requires a b equal to zero and that we don't allow it in IIDM. No?
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: This check might actually not be useful for non linear shunt (see above). Maybe there are shunt that can be considered as disconnected in several positions.
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: The check has to be removed (see above).
replies.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText: Yes great, so we can leave the check!
timeline.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText: Great!
timeline.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText: Why? It should be possible to have 0 section activated?
timeline.author: geofjamg

+ * It is expected to be greater than one and lesser than or equal to the

replies.bodyText: By default for me when 0 section is activated, it means that there is zero susceptance and admittance (cf. answer above)

replies.bodyText: doc should be updated?

timeline.bodyText: Is it really necessary to keep the number, if we keep all of them in the right order?
timeline.author: geofjamg

replies.bodyText: In my opinion, it makes it less efficient in cases when we are not sure in which order we receive the sections during the building (typically the case in CGMES). However, it makes the implementation less heavy (no need to use a map), what do you think?
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText:
I would not change the top level equipment name. This is really confusing.
Why not:
<iidm:shunt ...>
    <iidm:shuntLinearModel ... />

+

timeline.bodyText: Is it just for debugging?

replies.bodyText: No, this is a bit complicated for what it does, but it is to check that if the conductance of one section has been defined, all sections must have defined conductance (and vice versa, if a section with an undefined conductance has been added, all sections must have undefined conductances).
